Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Quantum Wires and Dots for Optoelectronic Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The market for high power lasers is exploding due to the popularity of laser welders for manufacturing and metal 3D printers. This project aims to demonstrate high electricity-to-light conversion efficiency for light emitting diodes (LED) and diode lasers. LED lighting bulbs will be brighter at the same energy used if they are more efficient in converting electricity into light. The demonstration will be based on novel nanostructures: quantum wires. Current state-of-the-art LEDs and diode lasers are based on the concept of quantum wells, even though higher efficiencies have been predicted from devices based on smaller nanostructures such as quantum wires. Preliminary results from the work conducted by this team suggest a novel route to fabricate quality quantum wires and their subsequent uses for high efficiency LEDs and lasers.

Fabrication of quality nanostructures by direct laser modification of surfaces has been regarded problematic due to laser induced defects, especially irradiation of high power laser pulses on III-V semiconductors has been known to induce damages since 1980. However, preliminary data from GaAs(001) surfaces that are irradiated by high power laser pulses suggest that the laser produced nanoscale features, if smaller than 100 nm, are free from chemical damages when the interferential irradiation of laser pulses creates transient thermal gratings on the surfaces. The demonstration of quality nanostructures as gain media for optoelectronic devices is fundamentally important because it is applicable to other material systems in order to usher the across-the-board efficiency increase for optoelectronic devices. If successful, developed direct laser fabrication techniques will be employed to realize proof-of-concept, diode lasers that are based on novel quantum wires.

Institution.Name: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: SOUTH DAKOTA SCHOOL OF MINES & TECHNOLOGY

Performance_Institution.Name: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most significant outcome of the project entitled “I-Corps: Quantum Wires and Dots for Optoelectronic Devices” is that a limited liability company has been created by the PI. The name of this company is “Rapid NanoTech LLC”. The company name has been registered at the South Dakota office of Secretary of State, on October 2015. Also Dun and Bradstreet (DUNS) number for the company has been assigned. The assigned DUNS number is 080035567. A DUNS number is necessary for a company to compete and win federal government projects such as small business innovational research (SBIR) projects. The PI is the owner and member of Rapid NanoTech LLC. The PI will pursue federal grants with his company as a partner in other to develop and market commercial products based on the outcomes of previous NSF projects.

A team has been formed for the project before the start of the project. The team consist of a graduate student, Ms. Anahita Haghizadeh, as Entrepreneurial Lead (EL), her advisor Dr. Haeyeon Yang as PI, and Mr. Darren Haar as Industrial Mentor (IM). IM Mr. Haar has been very helpful in advising the team for the potential interviewees. Also he has been vital to help creation and registration of Rapid NanoTech.

A notable outcome from EL is her winning of the top place in business plan competition on campus. This is exactly what the NSF I-Corps program expects from the participants as one of primary goals of the project was to expose the involved graduate student to business environment. Ms. Anahita Haghizadeh has undergone more than 100 interviews including her own site interviews at Los Angeles for five days. The interviews were planned ahead of her travel and executed by herself, providing her the most valuable experience to directly talk to potential customers. The project had also supported an undergraduate student, Mr. Yun Gwon. The EL and Mr. Yun Gwon have been encouraged to participate 8-week long entrepreneurial program called “Engineers Make Great Entrepreneurs.” Both students participated to the program and the EL, Ms. Haghizadeh’s business plan has won the top place in business plan competition held at the end of the program on October 2015 with a cash prize.

Another direct outcome of the NSF I-Corps project is PI’s winning of additional funding from the State of South Dakota. The NSF award was crucial for the PI to win a funding of $22,000 from the Governor’s Office Economic Development (GOED) for the duration from November 2015 to November 2016. This is because part of the NSF I-Corps grant was allocated as matching fund that is required by the GOED. The winning of the GOED funding was possible because the nature of the I-Corps project is quite similar to the PI’s project of the GOED funding concept since the State of South Dakota also encourage the innovative business activities. The funding will help the PI’s team to further the fabrication of proof-of-concept devices. The project funding will continue to support the undergraduate student as well as research and business activities of graduate students.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.
